articles.headline: Anxious Depositors Withdraw Cash From Asian Bank
articles.snippet: The Bank of East Asia is deemed stable by regulators and analysts, but many of its customers are taking no chances.
articles.abstract: The Bank of East Asia is deemed stable by regulators and analysts, but many of its customers are taking no chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Throngs of depositors lined up outside the headquarters and branches of the Bank of East Asia here on Wednesday to withdraw their money, highlighting widespread anxiety in Asia that Wall Street’s recent difficulties might spread across the Pacific.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Managing the Bailout: He’d Do It for Nothing
articles.snippet: William H. Gross, the manager of the country’s largest bond mutual fund, has a solution for keeping Wall Street firms from making a killing on the proposed financial bailout.
articles.abstract: William H. Gross, the manager of the country’s largest bond mutual fund, has a solution for keeping Wall Street firms from making a killing on the proposed financial bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — One of the chief concerns about the Treasury Department’s $700 billion bailout plan is that the same Wall Street firms that helped create the crisis could make a killing cleaning it up.

articles.headline: A New Generation, Poised to Reinvent
articles.snippet: A new book argues that growing interest in diversity and social responsibility is changing the way companies need to reach consumers.
articles.abstract: A new book argues that growing interest in diversity and social responsibility is changing the way companies need to reach consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GROWING interest in cultural pursuits, diversity, authenticity and social responsibility is changing the way companies need to reach consumers, a new book argues.

articles.headline: Really Feeling the Music
articles.snippet: Two new earbuds that pass audio signals directly through your bones or cartilage would be perfect, if they weren’t so flawed in their own ways.
articles.abstract: Two new earbuds that pass audio signals directly through your bones or cartilage would be perfect, if they weren’t so flawed in their own ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that Apple has sold 160 million iPods, reshaped the music business and inspired dozens of competitors, maybe it’s time to admit it: this music player thing might be more than a fad.

articles.headline: Bush and Candidates to Meet on Bailout
articles.snippet: President Bush invited the presidential candidates to the White House for talks on the economic crisis and called on Americans to support the recovery plan.
articles.abstract: President Bush invited the presidential candidates to the White House for talks on the economic crisis and called on Americans to support the recovery plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush appealed to the nation Wednesday night to support a $700 billion plan to avert a widespread financial meltdown, and signaled that he is willing to accept tougher controls over how the money is spent.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Plan’s Mystery: What’s All This Stuff Worth?
articles.snippet: Washington will struggle to put a price on the troubled investments at the heart of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Washington will struggle to put a price on the troubled investments at the heart of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would you pay, sight unseen, for a house that nobody wants, on a hard-luck street where no houses are selling?

articles.headline: First Debate Up in Air as McCain Steps Off the Trail
articles.snippet: John McCain vowed to work on the bailout plan, but Barack Obama rejected his call to delay the debate.
articles.abstract: John McCain vowed to work on the bailout plan, but Barack Obama rejected his call to delay the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Declaring that it was time to “set politics aside,” Senator John McCain said Wednesday that he would temporarily stop campaigning and seek to delay Friday’s debate with Senator Barack Obama to return to Washington to help forge an agreement on a proposed $700 billion bailout of financial institutions before Congress.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Could Warren Buffett Negotiate a Better Deal for Taxpayers?
articles.snippet: The federal government should follow the example of investment set by Warren Buffett.
articles.abstract: The federal government should follow the example of investment set by Warren Buffett.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe the American taxpayers should be asking Warren Buffett to be negotiating on their behalf.

articles.headline: As Stocks Rally, Credit Markets Appear Frozen
articles.snippet: While stocks rose as investors waited for lawmakers in Washington to determine the final structure of the government’s plan, the anxiety gripping the credit markets barely abated.
articles.abstract: While stocks rose as investors waited for lawmakers in Washington to determine the final structure of the government’s plan, the anxiety gripping the credit markets barely abated.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington dickered, Wall Street waited.

articles.headline: G.E. Cuts Outlook, Citing Ills on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s woes are hurting General Electric, raising fresh concerns that the impact of the financial turmoil will be severe on business profits and the wider economy.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s woes are hurting General Electric, raising fresh concerns that the impact of the financial turmoil will be severe on business profits and the wider economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s woes are hurting General Electric, a corporate bellwether, raising fresh concerns that the impact of the financial turmoil will be severe on business profits and the wider economy.
